docs.lead_paragraph: HEART disease patients who are taking medicine to lower their cholesterol are at a heightened risk for depression, according to research being reported today at a meeting of the American Psychosomatic Society in New Orleans. Men being treated for heart disease with lipid-lowering drugs reported signs of depression like being guilt-ridden and crying more frequently than did heart disease patients who were not on the drugs. The men on medication also reported higher levels of anxiety and worry and more frequent thoughts of suicide.

headline.main: Use of Drugs to Lower Cholesterol Is Tied to a Higher Depression Risk
